case_vignette:
A 36-year-old male with a past medical history of poorly controlled Crohn's disease presents for evaluation of a painful non-healing wound on the left lower leg. Patient endorses a pus bump developing on the left leg two months ago which he initially thought was a spider bite but eventually popped open. He was seen at urgent care a month ago and received one week course of cephalexin without any improvement. Local debridement attempts at bedside by the urgent care provider resulted in significant expansion of the ulcer. Physical examination reveals a well demarcated ovoid ulcer on the left distal shin with violaceous, rolled borders and cribriform base with yellow-red exudate.  The patient is afebrile and has no systemic symptoms. The patient is a 36-year-old female with a past medical history of poorly controlled Crohn's disease presents for evaluation of a painful non-healing wound on the left lower leg. Patient endorses a pus bump developing on the left leg two months ago which she initially thought was a spider bite but eventually popped open. She was seen at urgent care a month ago and received one week course of cephalexin without any improvement. Local debridement attempts at bedside by the urgent care provider resulted in significant expansion of the ulcer. Physical examination reveals a well demarcated ovoid ulcer on the left distal shin with violaceous, rolled borders and cribriform base with yellow-red exudate.  The patient is afebrile and has no systemic symptoms.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I am experiencing a painful non-healing wound on my left lower leg.
How long has the wound been present?
The wound has been present for two months.
Do you have any pre-existing conditions like diabetes or circulatory problems?
I have a pre-existing condition of poorly controlled Crohn's disease.
Have you noticed any changes in the skin around the wound, like scaling or dark discoloration?
No, I have not noticed any scaling or dark discoloration around the wound.
Have you had treatments or injuries in the area of the wound before it appeared?
No, I have not had any treatments or injuries in the area of the wound before it appeared.
Is there any history of similar skin issues in your family?
No, there is no history of similar skin issues in my family.
Have you taken any medications recently that might affect wound healing, such as steroids or immunosuppressants?
No, I have not taken any medications like steroids or immunosuppressants that might affect wound healing recently.
**Final Diagnosis:** Pyoderma gangrenosum.
